awd_titl_txt: Nanohoops as Modular Building Blocks to Molecular Cylinders and Machines
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Ramesh Jasti at the University of Oregon is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program of the Division of Chemistry to develop general methods to use nanohoop molecules as building blocks to self-assemble into precise nanoscale materials with controlled shape and function.   Two forms of structures are envisioned:  nanotubes and interlocked structures.  Novel synthetic approaches are explored to achieve these objectives. The desired products are expected to have structural stability and unique size-dependent optoelectronic properties.  The products are rationally designed to perform specific functions in gas adsorption, filtration, mass transport, and molecular switching and sensing.  Nanotubes with controlled geometry and diameter are used to prepare one-dimensional materials from fullerenes (soccer-like) carbon-based molecules.  Students involved in the project are trained in an interdisciplinary environment and acquire experience in organic synthesis, supramolecular chemistry, and nanoscience.  A partnership with the University of Oregon Summer Science Program provides hands-on science experience to groups of students who are traditionally underrepresented in the state of Oregon. 
  
The assembly of molecular building blocks into precise nanoscale materials with novel function is a grand challenge at the interfaces of materials science, supramolecular chemistry, and synthesis.  While synthetic approaches for the preparation of nanohoops have been developed in the last decade, the self-assembly of these nanohoops into nanoscale materials with controlled shape and function is relatively unexplored.  In the first aim of this project, the Jasti research team is exploring weak aryl fluorine interactions as means to guide the self-assembly of carbon nanohoops into noncovalent nanotubes.  The nanotubes are used to self-assemble fullerenes into 1D channels, which can then undergo a polymerization reaction to lead to a host of new 1D fullerene nanomaterials.  In the second aim of the project, the Jasti group is exploring nitrogen-doped nanohoop analogues and metal-coordination strategies to prepare catenane structures, which would represent simple versions of molecular machines.  The Jasti group is probing these new catenane structures for novel properties such as optoelectronic communication through the mechanical bond or ultra-low friction motion on the nanoscale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Molecules with radially oriented pi-systems have been appreciated by chemists for decades, but have recently undergone a renaissance in that new developments in synthetic methodology have rendered what were previously mostly theoretical curiosities into now accessible structures. Although these molecules can now be synthesized, studies related to self-assembly and design of larger assembled structures using these building blocks is a relatively untapped field. In this grant period, we sought to prepare and study the properties of non-covalent cylindrical structures and mechanically interlocked molecules built from macrocycles with these radially-oriented pi-systems.

 

With regards to assembling noncovalent nanotubes, we designed nanohoops with fluorination patterns that we hypothesized would lead to noncovalent nanotubes held together by weak forces. Indeed we were able to show that this can be realized for two different diameter nanohoops and we also demonstrated that these structures could be self-assembled onto a graphite structure. These highly fluorescent structures were very uniform in diameter with hundreds of channels running through each self-assembled crystal, reminiscent of carbon nanotube “forests.”  The channels are very precisely defined by the diameter of the starting material nanohoop, which gives channels below two nanometers in diameter. In a subsequent study, we were able to show that these channels can also host guest molecules, in particular fullerene. Moreover, the channels are accessible by gases which allowed us to assess the surface area, which is over 600 square meters per gram for this carbon nanomaterial. We were also able to develop the first mechanically interlocked nanohoop structures using an active template approach.  Using this method, we were able to show rotaxane designs that can sense fluoride and H2S by turn on fluorescence.  Finally, we have adapted this method to generate a wide variety of catenane structures which can contain two or even three interlocked nanohoop rings of varying sizes. Studying the dynamics as well as the optical and electrical properties of these new materials is now possible.

 

From a broader impacts perspective, one of the central missions of this grant was to provide educational experiences that bring interdisciplinary science and nanoscience to a broad range of students. Over the course of the grant period, five graduate students worked on the proposal (to varying degrees), with three of them already receiving their PhD and two more working towards their doctoral degree. A total of five undergraduates have also worked on various aspects of this proposal. Finally, the self-assembly of the fluorinated nanohoops have led many other labs to pursue similar ideas with other pi conjugated macrocycles. Also, at the time of this proposal, there were no known pi conjugated rotaxanes or catenanes. Since our work, numerous research groups all over the world have utilized our methods and developed others to prepare mechanically interlocked nanohoop structures. Mechanically interlocked molecules made from carbon nanostructures is currently undergoing a revolution which should bring dynamic motion to the world of carbon nanoscience.

 


Last Modified: 12/16/2022
Modified by: Ramesh Jasti
